title: 113_hr4251
content: The Act is known as the "National Traumatic Brain Injury Research and Treatment Improvement Act of 2014". It includes findings related to traumatic brain injuries. The "National Traumatic Brain Injury Research and Treatment Improvement Act of 2014" includes findings on state data systems providing reliable injury data, emerging causes of traumatic brain injury, such as military-related injuries and sports-related concussions, and the need for cause-specific prevention strategies. In their 2013 report, the Institute of Medicine and the National Research Council highlighted the lack of data on sports-related concussions in youth. They recommended the establishment of a national surveillance system by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to accurately determine the incidence of concussions in youth aged 5 to 21. Traumatic brain injury is a significant public health issue among older individuals. The need for cost-effective prevention measures for traumatic brain injury in older persons is urgent as the population continues to grow. Collaboration with various Federal agencies, school systems, and State agencies is necessary to implement the Act effectively. Establishing requirements to improve research and treatment of traumatic brain injury. The Secretary will evaluate existing surveillance systems for traumatic brain injury, submit a report to Congress, and establish the National Traumatic Brain Injury Surveillance System. This system will facilitate further research on brain injury. The Secretary will collect and store information on traumatic brain injury in the United States, including demographics and other associated information like age, race, sex, geographic location, and history of head injury. The Secretary will collect and store information on traumatic brain injury in the United States, including demographics like age, race, sex, and geographic location, as well as history of head injury. Additionally, information on traumatic brain injury analysis will include impact location, personnel qualifications, assessment tools, signs and symptoms, and details on the sport or activity. The Secretary will consult with experts on traumatic brain injury, including epidemiologists, national health associations focusing on brain injury, and state public health agencies. This consultation will address issues identified during the data collection process. The Secretary may award grants to public or private nonprofit entities for activities related to traumatic brain injury surveillance. Coordination with other federal agencies is required to make information from the National Traumatic Brain Injury Surveillance System available. The Secretary is responsible for making information from the National Traumatic Brain Injury Surveillance System available to various Federal departments and agencies. Public access to this information is also ensured, with privacy protections in place similar to HIPAA laws. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the implementation of the National Traumatic Brain Injury Surveillance System, including details on information collected, guidelines for use, and coordination of databases. The term "HIPAA privacy and security law" refers to the law defined in section 3009 of the Public Health Service Act. "Personally identifiable information" includes data that can identify an individual, such as their name or social security number. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The term "surveillance" refers to the systematic collection, analysis, and dissemination of health-related data for public health action. "Traumatic brain injury" is defined as head injury from various causes. Authorization of appropriations is required to implement this Act. Authorization of appropriations is necessary to carry out this Act.
